awd_titl_txt: Conference: NAIRR: Strengthening & Democratizing The U.S. AI Innovation Ecosystem Summit
awd_abstract_narration:
After 18 months of public meetings and deliberation, the National AI Research Resource (NAIRR) Task Force fulfilled its Congressional mandate, unanimously approving a guide to the policy and practical aspects of building a national resource for AI research. This process has been deliberative and included a wide range of stakeholders in considering an effective and equitable method of making resources for AI research -- including computing power, data, toolkits, and more -- available to a broader universe of researchers. With the advent of modern AI, this form of collaborative yet broadened investment has been deemed necessary by Congress and the Administration, and presents a necessary step forward to grow the U.S. scientific enterprise. 

The objective of this workshop is to explore the findings of the National AI Research Resource Task Force's final report with a diverse group of stakeholders from the broader ecosystem, and to then determine practical next steps to begin building such a resource using existing and future mechanisms. In addition to the diverse cohort of attendees, a recorded live stream subsequent reporting will further disseminate workshop outcomes to the public.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
Project Overview

The NAIRR (National Artificial Intelligence Research Resource) summit, hosted by SeedAI on March 1, 2023, gathered stakeholders across disciplines to explore, discuss, understand, and operationalize the recommendations of the NAIRR Task Force. 

This one-day summit brought together over 150 attendees, speakers, and staff including leaders from academia, government, and the private sector, to explore the creation of an inclusive AI workforce and ecosystem in the U.S. The summit featured panel discussions, fireside chats, and direct conversations with experts on AI innovation and policy topics.

Major Goals and Accomplishments

The primary goal of the summit was to activate the recommendations from the NAIRR Task Force report and to foster a deep and diverse AI ecosystem from ideation to end-use. This was achieved through the following key activities:

Planning and Coordination:

  • Established a diverse organizing committee to steer the summit's direction and ensure alignment with objectives.

  • Conducted detailed planning sessions to develop the event content and logistics.

  • Recruited high-quality speakers representing a spectrum of perspectives and backgrounds, ensuring diverse representation in summit discussions.

Event Execution:

 

  • SeedAI hosted a summit at the Hyatt Regency Washington on Capitol Hill, bringing together 101 in-person attendees, plus leaders from academia, government, and the private sector, to explore the cultivation of an inclusive AI workforce and ecosystem in the U.S.

  • Provided comprehensive accommodations for attendees, including hosting a live stream for remote participants.

  • Conducted four panel discussions, two armchair discussions, and two interactive talks to cover crucial topics such as AI democratization, recent AI breakthroughs, and advancing trustworthy AI through NAIRR.

Post-Event Dissemination:

  • Created a video highlighting conference insights and documenting the event. This video is available on the SeedAI website for continued dissemination.

  • Continued communications with key stakeholders to drive the recommendations forward and integrate feedback into future planning.

Key Outcomes

The summit successfully achieved several significant results:

Stakeholder Engagement:

  • Cultivated a diverse network of invested individuals and organizations committed to implementing NAIRR recommendations and driving AI democratization.

  • Identified strategies to advance recommendations and challenges addressed during the summit.

Training and Professional Development:

  • While not conceived for this purpose, the project spurred the development of two groundbreaking training initiatives: the Generative Red Team Challenge and the Hack the Future series. These programs are designed to equip underrepresented communities with AI education, including development, evaluation, and workforce applications.

Policy and Ecosystem Development:

  • Facilitated the creation of a more robust, inclusive AI ecosystem, connecting stakeholders and aligning efforts with national science and technology goals.

  • Produced actionable recommendations for policymakers and industry leaders to strengthen partnerships and cultivate AI expertise in communities across the U.S.

Impact on the Discipline and Broader Community

The NAIRR summit had a profound impact on both the AI discipline and the broader community:

Advancement in AI Research and Development:

  • Highlighted the need for a comprehensive, innovative, and inclusive infrastructure to support AI from conception to end-use.

  • Encouraged collaboration among policymakers, industry leaders, and academic researchers to foster innovation and address the ethical and societal implications of AI.

Educational and Workforce Development:

  • Addressed the importance of including underrepresented groups in AI education and career pathways, promoting diversity and equity in technology fields.

  • Emphasized the critical role education plays in developing a competitive AI workforce.

Societal and Technological Contributions:

  • Contributed to discussions on how AI can address large-scale social and geopolitical issues, including revitalizing the manufacturing industry and job creation.

  • Strengthened the position of the U.S. as a leader in AI by bringing together stakeholders across various sectors and industries to build an interconnected, inclusive AI ecosystem.

Future Plans

Moving forward, SeedAI plans to build on the success of the NAIRR summit by:

Continued Stakeholder Engagement:

  • Maintaining and expanding the network of stakeholders involved in AI innovation and policy.

  • Organizing follow-up events and initiatives to keep the momentum and drive forward the recommendations.

Enhanced Training and Development Programs:

  • Scaling up the Generative Red Team Challenge and Hack the Future series to reach more communities.

  • Developing new training modules and workshops based on feedback and emerging needs.

Ongoing Policy Advocacy and Implementation:

  • Working closely with the Congressional AI Caucus and other policymakers to ensure the NAIRR recommendations are integrated into national strategies and emerging policies.

  • Monitoring and evaluating the impact of implemented and proposed policies, adjusting strategies to achieve the desired outcomes.

 Conclusion

The NAIRR summit marked a significant step towards democratizing AI innovation and creating an inclusive ecosystem that benefits all Americans. By bringing together diverse stakeholders and focusing on actionable outcomes, the summit laid the groundwork for a future where AI technology drives national growth and prosperity with a workforce that truly represents the diversity of the American people.


Last Modified: 05/17/2024
Modified by: Austin Carson
